results.title: Oscars Rewind: For Halle Berry, a Bittersweet Breakthrough
results.abstract: Since she won best actress for “Monster’s Ball,” no other Black woman has taken the prize, a fact she calls “heartbreaking.”

results.title: Danny Glover on Acting, Activism and His Honorary Oscar
results.abstract: The actor and producer is receiving the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award at the Oscars. Here, he discusses a history in movies and in social justice.

multimedia.caption: “I’m an actor first because of my activism,” Danny Glover said. He has served as a Goodwill Ambassador both for UNICEF and the United Nations Development Program.
multimedia.copyright: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times

results.title: 100 Years of ‘Nosferatu,’ the Vampire Movie That Won’t Die
results.abstract: F.W. Murnau’s 1922 silent film continues to live on in the popular imagination, as a fairy tale, a meme and a cinematic revenant.

multimedia.caption: The shadow of Max Schreck as Count Orlok in a famous scene from “Nosferatu.”
The shadow of Max Schreck as Count Orlok in a famous scene from “Nosferatu.”

results.title: ‘Basic Instinct’ at 30: A Time Capsule That Can Still Offend
results.abstract: The erotic thriller starring Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone was a big hit that set off protests in its day, and it’s easy to see why even now.

multimedia.caption: Sharon Stone in the interrogation scene in “Basic Instinct,” which opened on March 20, 1992.
Sharon Stone in the interrogation scene in “Basic Instinct,” which opened on March 20, 1992.

results.title: After Criticism, Film Museum Will Highlight Hollywood’s Jewish History
results.abstract: The new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, which tried to present an inclusive history of film, overlooked the role Jewish immigrants played in creating the industry.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: The new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, which was criticized for overlooking the role Jewish immigrants played in creating the industry, is planning to make up for the omission with a new permanent exhibition next year.
multimedia.copyright: Rozette Rago for The New York Times

results.title: Peter Bowles, Actor in ‘To the Manor Born,’ Dies at 85
results.abstract: In a six-decade career in TV, film and onstage, he played comedy and drama, hapless heroes and villains, often with the air of the archetypal English gent.

multimedia.caption: Peter Bowles in “To the Manor Born,” the long-running British comedy series (also shown on PBS) about a nouveau-riche owner of a supermarket who buys a grand English manor house.

results.title: Jack Willis, TV Producer and Empathetic Filmmaker, Dies at 87
results.abstract: A survivor of a crippling accident, his documentaries and news coverage for public television focused on poverty, race and other social issues.

multimedia.caption: Jack Willis im 1971. His commitment to civil rights was reflected in his enduring friendship with the singer and activist Harry Belafonte, who called him “a soul brother.”
multimedia.copyright: Don West Broadcasting & Cable collection, Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries. Photo by L.M. Romano
